pullRequest.body:
Implement a tactic that proves tautologies involving hypotheses and goals of the form `X ‚äÜ Y` or `X = Y`, where `X`, `Y` are expressions built using ‚à™, ‚à©, \, and ·∂ú from finitely many variables of type `Set Œ±`.  It also unfolds Disjoint and symmDiff.

Discussed in the zulip thread https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Trivialities.20about.20sets

The file MathlibTest/TautoSet.lean contains many usage example, including a list of lemma's from the Matroid Decomposition Theorem Verification project, which can now be golfed to a single tactic invocation.

nodes.body:
### PR summary [b8a63c5ff7](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20706/commits/b8a63c5ff7f8d115c15e49f9488eb92366a8ed37)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Tactic`|1|
| `Mathlib.Tactic.TautoSet` (new file)|222|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

No declarations were harmed in the making of this PR! üêô
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Maybe mention `Disjoint` in the PR description as well?

Good question! I thought a bit about this and could not easily think of a good use case. Even here it is used rather crudely (I guess it would be more efficient and elegant to filter out the hypotheses that have the correct type before trying specialize on them).
I would probably move it two lines lower, just for easier reading in case somebody wants to check the implementation of the tactic.
Not sure if I understood correctly what you intend, but I introduced two empty lines above the macro declaration

```suggestion
example (hAB : A ‚äÜ B) (hBC : B ‚äÜ C) (hCD : C ‚äÜ D) (hDE : D = E) (hEA : E ‚äÜ A) :
```

```suggestion
example {X Y : Set Œ±} : X \ (X ‚à© Y) ‚à™ Y = X ‚à™ Y := by tauto_set
```

```suggestion
example (hABC : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C) (hCD : C ‚äÜ D): A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ D := by tauto_set
```

```suggestion
example (hAB : Disjoint A B) (hCA : C ‚äÜ A) : Disjoint C (B \ D) := by tauto_set
```

```suggestion
example (hAB : A ‚äÜ B) (hCD : C ‚äÜ D) : C \ B ‚äÜ D \ A := by tauto_set
```
4 spaces when you continue existing declaration
It doesn't matter for examples; however, I would make them all implicit nevertheless.

pullRequest.title: feat: implement tauto_set tactic for set-theoretic trivialities
